TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal charges were brought against the applicant . He was suspected of armed robberies , committed in an organised criminal group . The applicant was in hiding at the material time .

CARDINAL . On DATE an arrest warrant was issued against the applicant by the NORP authorities . After having been unsuccessfully sought for DATE , he was eventually detained in GPE on DATE and remanded in custody .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , action was taken with a view to the applicant 's extradition and on DATE , the NORP authorities handed him over to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered that the applicant remain in custody , relying on the reasonable suspicion that he had committed the offences in question . The court considered that keeping the applicant in detention was necessary to secure the proper conduct of the proceedings , given the risk that he might tamper with evidence and induce witnesses to give false testimony or go underground again ( he had earlier been in hiding in GPE ) . It further stressed the severity of the anticipated penalty and the fact that the applicant had been acting in an organised criminal group .

CARDINAL . The applicant 's appeal against the detention order was dismissed by ORG on DATE . Likewise , his further appeals against decisions prolonging his detention and all his subsequent , numerous applications for release and appeals against refusals to release him were unsuccessful . In his applications and appeals he relied on his personal circumstances , in particular his poor health , stressing that he had been infected with an ORG virus .

CARDINAL . In the course of the investigation , the applicant 's detention was prolonged on several occasions , namely by ORG decisions of DATE , DATE and DATE , DATE and DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE , DATE and DATE and ORG decisions of DATE and DATE . In all their detention decisions the authorities repeatedly relied on the original grounds given for the applicant 's detention . In addition , they stressed the existence of a strong suspicion that the applicant had committed the offences in question , which was supported by an extensive body of evidence from witnesses and experts . Further , they attached importance to the grave nature of the charges against him and the fact that a “ wanted ” notice had been issued for his arrest .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG filed a bill of indictment with ORG . The applicant was charged with inter alia numerous counts of armed robberies committed in an organised criminal group .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG requested ORG that the case be transferred to ORG . The court stressed the special nature of the case , which implied that exceptional security measures be taken and special facilities provided . On DATE ORG granted the request .
CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant served a prison sentence imposed in another set of criminal proceedings ( on the strength of ORG judgment of DATE ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the applicant 's request to be released on bail . On DATE the applicant was released as he had paid bail of MONEY ( ORG ) .
CARDINAL . It appears that the criminal proceedings are still pending .
